perturbation.original_text: 5.4Acceptance, Rejection, and Claims. APOLLO may inspect any or all shipments of Product to insure all specifications are met including proper labeling, packaging and count within thirty (30) business days of APOLLO's receipt of each shipment; however, any such inspection shall not relieve ESTABLISHMENT of any obligations or warranties under this Agreement. APOLLO has the right to reject, via written notification to ESTABLISHMENT within this thirty (30) day period, any or all of a shipment of Product that fails to satisfy any warranty in this Agreement and may reject all of a given Lot of Product if a statistical sample does not meet the Specifications. Upon confirmation of defective condition by ESTABLISHMENT and issuance of a return material authorization ("RMA") number, APOLLO shall be entitled to the immediate return and replacement, free of charge, of any Product supplied by ESTABLISHMENT in breach of any warranty under this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 5.4Acceptance, Rejection, and Claims. APOLLO may inspect any or all shipments of Product to insure all specifications are met including proper labeling, packaging and count within ten (10) business days of APOLLO's receipt of each shipment; however, any such inspection shall not relieve ESTABLISHMENT of any obligations or warranties under this Agreement. APOLLO has the right to reject, via written notification to ESTABLISHMENT within this ten (10) day period, any or all of a shipment of Product that fails to satisfy any warranty in this Agreement and may reject all of a given Lot of Product if a statistical sample does not meet the Specifications. Upon confirmation of defective condition by ESTABLISHMENT and issuance of a return material authorization ("RMA") number, APOLLO shall be entitled to the immediate return and replacement, free of charge, of any Product supplied by ESTABLISHMENT in breach of any warranty under this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the inspection and rejection period from 30 days to 10 days may be unreasonably short, potentially violating implied warranty laws or the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC), which generally requires a reasonable time for inspection and rejection. This alteration could prejudice APOLLO's rights to discover latent defects.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) - Implied Warranty and Acceptance/Rejection provisions.

perturbation.original_text: Each Party's agreement to indemnify, defend and hold the other harmless is conditioned on the indemnified Party (i) providing written notice to the indemnifying Party of any claim, demand or action arising out of the indemnified activities within thirty (30) days after the indemnified Party has knowledge of such claim, demand or action; (ii) permitting the indemnifying Party to assume full responsibility to investigate, prepare for and defend against any such claim or demand; (iii) assisting the indemnifying Party, at the indemnifying Party's reasonable expense, in the investigation of, preparation for and defense of any such claim or demand; and (iv) not compromising or settling such claim or demand without the indemnifying Party's written consent; provided, however, that the failure of the indemnified Party to undertake any of the foregoing actions shall not relieve the indemnifying Party of any obligation it may have under this Article 8, except to the extent that the indemnifying Party's ability to fulfill such obligation has been materially prejudiced thereby.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party's agreement to indemnify, defend and hold the other harmless is conditioned on the indemnified Party (i) providing written notice to the indemnifying Party of any claim, demand or action arising out of the indemnified activities within five (5) days after the indemnified Party has knowledge of such claim, demand or action; (ii) permitting the indemnifying Party to assume full responsibility to investigate, prepare for and defend against any such claim or demand; (iii) assisting the indemnifying Party, at the indemnifying Party's reasonable expense, in the investigation of, preparation for and defense of any such claim or demand; and (iv) not compromising or settling such claim or demand without the indemnifying Party's written consent; provided, however, that the failure of the indemnified Party to undertake any of the foregoing actions shall not relieve the indemnifying Party of any obligation it may have under this Article 8, except to the extent that the indemnifying Party's ability to fulfill such obligation has been materially prejudiced thereby.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notification period for indemnification claims from 30 days to 5 days is unreasonably short. This could violate fair notice principles and hinder the indemnified party's ability to properly investigate and prepare a defense, potentially conflicting with established legal standards for reasonable notice.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common Law - Principles of reasonable notice in indemnification claims.

perturbation.original_text: Establishment shall retain such records for five (5) years following the date of manufacture, or such longer period of time if consistent with Regulatory Standards, and shall make available to Apollo copies of such records; and upon the expiration of such period, Establishment shall contact Apollo and give Apollo the option to have such quality control documentation transferred to Apollo or destroyed.
perturbation.changed_text: Establishment shall retain such records for one (1) year following the date of manufacture, or such longer period of time if consistent with Regulatory Standards, and shall make available to Apollo copies of such records; and upon the expiration of such period, Establishment shall contact Apollo and give Apollo the option to have such quality control documentation transferred to Apollo or destroyed.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the record retention period from five years to one year for manufacturing and quality control records contradicts FDA requirements (21 CFR Part 820) for medical device manufacturers, which mandate longer retention periods to ensure traceability and compliance. This poses a significant regulatory risk for APOLLO, the medical device company.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 21 CFR Part 820 - FDA Quality System Regulations for medical devices.
